answers.answer: Dehydration can cause what you describe. With dehydration you feel okay lying down, very tired, and the problems begin when you stand up.  Your blood pressure drops and because of this you become lightheaded and can pass out.  Did your doctor give you any ideas on how to stay hydrated besides drinking water?  When we become dehydrated we also lose electrolytes, which can be dangerous and they need to be replaced.  Eating a banana every day is good, drinking orange juice, and Gatorade will replenish your electrolytes.  There is a Gatorade that is low in sugar and that's the one you want, or dilute the regular with some water for better absorption.  Did your doctor take your BP sitting and then standing....this would have told him a lot, especially if you're dehydrated.  It appears that your medication is causing your sugar to drop too low and creating your problems.  It drop and then spikes, he should be looking at this.  Although it's normal for our sugar to rise and drop throughout the day, it's not normal for it to rise too high or drop too low.  Is your doctor an Endocrinologist, they are best at managing your diabetes.  We can and do pass out when our sugar drops too low, so I think your doctor needs to address why it's happening.  I would eat a banana everyday and sip on Gatorade, and water. If it doesn't happen again, then you'll know it was dehydration. What did they tell you at the ER?  They would have known if it was dehydration and rehydrated you.  A report of this would have gone to your doctor, and then he would know.  I would also google your medications and see what the side effects are, because if they have a diuretic affect on you, your doctor should have been monitoring your potassium levels every 3 months.  My husband is diabetic, and they had him on a BP med with a diuretic in it for his high BP.  He started to not feel well and I asked him if they were checking his potassium level and he didn't know.  So they did and his potassium was very low.  He now takes a supplement for this and has had no more problems.  I hope this helps, it's very scary to be enduring what you are. I think it's good to question this, it doesn't sound like your doctor is taking it very seriously, maybe time to get a new doc? I wish you all the best and take care.

question: I am a 60 year old woman with Type II Diabetes.  I was diagnosed at the age of 46 and have never had any real problems other than some low and high sugar levels at times.  At least that was the case until nearly a month ago.  I was home and realized my sugar was low.  I checked it and it was sixty four (64).  That is low enough for me to start to feel really bad and want only to sleep.  I needed to do some shopping but knew I could not go to the store with a level that low.  So, I ate something and checked my level again.  It was then at ninety four (94) but I felt able to drive to the store and shop for the few items I needed.  Of course I went to Wal-Mart and after entering the store realized I could not focus on anything and my eyesight streadily became worse.  That is all I remember until I heard my name called and found out I had been transported to the hospital by ambulance and was in the ER.  I was diagnosed with low blood sugar.  I accepted that diagnosis then but unfortunately, three days later I woke up at 1:30 am and realized I felt a little strange.  I checked my sugar level and it was 164.  Then before I knew it I was waking up, lying on my kitchen floor.  I had no idea how long I had been out or remember anything after checking my blood sugar.  Ten days later I had another episode, the same as the first two.  I was hospitalized for four days, checked for heart valve blockage, and monitored.  Nothing happened, however my physician believed all of this fainting was because of two medications (Actos and Bumetinide) I was taking causing me to dehydrate causing my heart to pump harder but lacking to supply my brain with enough oxygen.  I am a little skeptible of this diagnosis and until reading some of the questions here was at a lost for what it might be.  This much I know....just before fainting I experienced the worse feeling I have ever felt in my life!  I am the mother of five children and I would rather go through all five childbirths at one time than to have that feeling again.  It's that bad for me.  My question is, are these diabetic seizures or is the doctor's diagnosis correct?  I am desperate to know before another episode may happen.
title: Diabetic Seizure?
